subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... I would prefer to have a common American way for the words bear and beer, so that reading and writing becomes easier, but I see the argument against
messageBody:
othermale wrote:
>
>
> You are very right and you have found a very cool case. It occurs
> as follows: As you know, different English language accents will
> phonetically write the same word differently. Thus Quickscript from
> different places will differ slightly. No surprises here.
> But the issue you have found is that the names and examples of
> letters and ligatures are themselves pronounced differently by
> different English speakers. Thus "eight" (name of a letter in QM) and
> "pair" (example used for a ligature in QM) have the same pronunciation
> in upper-class-British English but differ in 21st century American
> English. The author of the manual spoke
> commonwealth-British-like-English hence his examples would be correct
> for him and the educated English of the commonwealth. But not all of
> them work in 21st century America. Thus the US speaker should probably
> not use "pair" or "air" for that ligature because it does not have the
> right sound in our dialect (see below)
> Generally some of the examples and names of the letters and
> ligatures which are clear to one speaker could be ambiguous to
> another. This is one reason the names of letters must be chosen with
> immense care such that they are pronounced the same in all accents
> (which is no small task). I imagine this is why the QM gave letters
> "as in" rather than official names and why they are referred to by
> number frequently (though inconsistently)

I would prefer to have a common American way for the words "bear" and
"beer," so that reading and writing becomes easier, but I see the
argument against prescribing one way. As a matter of fact, I pronounce
these two words the same exact way. I would actually spell both
Bob-Eat-Roar. I can also see Bob-Eight-Roar. But in American English, I
cannot hear Bob-If-Roar, as I have seen some spellings.

If the ligatures are ambiguous, I wonder if they should be used? Or
should they be used literally, as a typecasters's tool, so that two
glyphs become merged to look better.

But above all this topic really shows the need for a standard mapping of
QS letters to IPA symbols. I can see that different people pronounce
words differently, but if each QS letter does not mean a very specific
sound, which should map to IPA, then the alphabet becomes ambiguous and
somewhat meaningless.

I have already created such a chart, but I need to work on its layout.
Then I would like to see what the group thinks about it.

Paul
